title: 111_hr3923
content: The Act is titled the "Sugar Loaf Fire Protection District Land Exchange Act" and includes definitions for clarity. The Act defines key terms such as "District" as the Sugar Loaf Fire Protection District in Boulder, Colorado, "Federal land" as specific parcels in the Arapaho-Roosevelt National Forest, "National Forest" as the forest in Colorado, and "non-Federal land" as a parcel in unincorporated Boulder County. The curr_chunk describes a 5.17-acre parcel of non-Federal land in unincorporated Boulder County, Colorado, depicted on a map titled "Sugarloaf Fire Protection District Proposed Land Exchange" dated November 12, 2009. The term "Secretary" refers to the Secretary of Agriculture. The curr_chunk describes a land exchange in unincorporated Boulder County, Colorado. The curr_chunk outlines the process for a land exchange between the District and the Secretary, with provisions for conveying non-Federal land to the Secretary and receiving Federal land in return. The exchange is subject to applicable laws, including the requirement for the District to cover costs related to surveys, appraisals, and administrative expenses. The land exchange agreement between the District and the Secretary includes provisions for allocating administrative costs, subject to valid existing rights and additional terms set by the Secretary. The exchange should be completed within 1 year, with the option for the Secretary to sell Federal land to the District at fair market value if the exchange is not completed on time. Proceeds from the sale will be handled accordingly. The Secretary will deposit proceeds from cash equalization payments and land sales into a fund for land acquisition in the National Forest. Non-Federal land acquired will be added to the National Forest and managed according to the Weeks Law. The Federal land will be managed according to the Weeks Law and any applicable laws. Public orders withdrawing the land are revoked to allow conveyance to the District, and the land is withdrawn until the conveyance is complete. The House of Representatives passed the document on July 13, 2010, with Lorraine C. Miller as the Clerk.
